replies: For younger people social security is a ponzi scheme, we aren't getting any of that money.

The problem is that politicians on both sides of the aisle borrowed money from it. It is going broke. The politicians will want you to pay more and get less to make it work. It is a Giant Ponzi scheme.

There are big (big, big) changes coming that play into this.  Robots ARE coming for our jobs, and that is a real and giant thing that most people don't get yet.  The nature of 'work' will look dramatically different in a decade.

The Social Security section of this works against itself.  Everyone under fifty has grown up being told it would be gone when they got to it.  It's basically a pyramid scheme when you include longer periods of retirement as life expectancy grows.  Good ideas can be poorly run.

Reductio ad absurdem is fun, but there are differences between government run services, which directly interact with the public, and military service, a function of national security. Invariably, the question of cost reduces the function of service, which degrades quality.
Okay, so are you advocating that we do away with the VA?

Not at all.  I'm saying that a system which answers for it's annual costs cannot adequately cover the promise we make to veterans when the cost for doing so rises. Small market.  Extending that mentality to national health care before we figure out how to improve is wreckless.

In sincerity though, you aren't wrong with how you're talking about systems. So next time just don't start a conversation with "Look at any government run industry." What you mean is some government systems need improvement, and you support that improvement.

I can see where the presumption of a different take on that would be possible.  Asking to clarify makes more sense for an actual conversation than assuming the worst take and running the person down.  I'll attempt to be clearer but limited space for loquaciousness in tweets.

My comments could have been more precise and contained in fewer tweets. I did not intend to overwhelm with strings of response, and if it felt that way I apologize. You've got every right to your opinions and I respect that.
